Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: 4D reconstruction algorithm for image guided interventions
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will prove the feasibility of a low-dose 4D cone beam tomosynthesis reconstruction algorithm for use in medical image-guided interventions. Despite the availability of highly accurate 3D guidance systems, most image-guided interventions are still performed under 2D fluoroscopy. 3D guidance is significantly more complex and expensive, as it requires the combination of 3D imaging (like CT) with surgical navigation, both expensive and complex technologies. A system capable of reconstructing a 4D scene would provide accurate and easy to use guidance for the medical professional, at lower costs. This research will develop a 3D reconstruction algorithm with quasi real-time performance (4D) that does not increase exposure to x-rays when compared to 2D fluoroscopy. The proposed technology will combine the most recent advancements in tomosynthesis, iterative reconstruction and compressed sensing and fundamentally change image-guided interventions.

The broader impact/commercial potential of this project is that advanced medical procedures, like minimally invasive surgery, will be significantly improved in workflow and accessibility, reducing healthcare costs, improving outcomes and improving quality of life for patients. In the U.S. alone, a 10% shift to minimally invasive spine surgeries can reduce healthcare costs by $180M while reducing patient trauma and providing faster recoveries to 45,000 patients. This technology could be applied in other clinical areas like oncology and interventional radiology, improving a broad array of procedures and bringing a new level of excellence in medical interventions. 4D systems would compete in the intra-operative x-ray medical imaging market, a $1B market that is growing 6% annually, and in the Surgical Navigation market, a $400M market that is growing 9% annually. The proposed concept has the potential to disrupt both these markets by replacing pairs of intra-operative 3D imaging and surgical navigation systems with one 4D system that is more cost effective and easier to use.

POR.DRECONTENT:
nView medical (nView) is developing a novel 4D x-ray scanner for surgery and minimally invasive procedures. nView’s goal is to improve surgical accuracy and simplify the surgical workflow to bring better outcomes to patients, cost efficiencies to hospitals and to simplify image guidance for surgeons. 

 

This NSF funded research proved the feasibility of this novel imaging approach by:

  1. Proving near-real-time performance of the 4D reconstruction algorithm at the core of the scanner,
  2. Demonstrating that this approach leads to higher surgeon observer accuracy, and by
  3. Building a test bench prtotype of a 4D micro-scanner to prove the concept

 

nView’s proprietary 4D reconstruction algorithm was implemented in commercially available GPUs proving near real-time performance, with a system latency of 440 ms. A user observer test demonstrated that nView’s 4D reconstructions lead to higher observer accuracy when compared to current imaging technologies (fluoroscopy and CBCT). Results were statistically significant. These findings were confirmed by the development of an x-ray test bench that demonstrated a physical realization of nView’s 4D scanner and performed the first 4D reconstruction in a tomosynthesis geometry (see attached image).

This SBIR project is advancing medical imaging technology by providing an intra-operative imaging system with real-time image-based instrument tracking. nView’s proposed technology combines the most recent advancements in tomosynthesis with model based non-linear iterative reconstruction techniques to provide a 4D scanner with a novel and proprietary system architecture that will significantly improve the ease of use of an image guided system while improving surgeon accuracy, reducing revision surgeries and improving the quality of care.

nView’s patent-pending system can disrupt and redefine the $2.4B image guidance market by replacing fluoroscopic, CBCT and surgical navigation systems with one 4D system that brings substantial economic benefits tied to a reduction of operating room utilization, a reduction of costly revision surgeries and lower equipment costs.
